title: How hard is it to be a physicist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Personally, I think it is very hard to be a physicist. As others have pointed out, it is very hard to become a physicist. The work required to succeed through college and graduate school is immense. The competition to find jobs, from post doctoral positions on, is very intense. There are very few jobs and many applicants. The politics involved in academia is notorious and well deserves its reputation. Also, the hours are very long and the pay is very small. (Just surviving on a physicist’s salary is hard!) And if all the above weren’t enough, then there is also the material itself. The problems to be solved, both in theoretical and experimental physics, are very difficult. If they were easy then someone would have solved them already! And I have found that even if I find a particularly elegant solution to a problem, one that is original and conceptually clear and seems simple in hindsight, then it is only after a long struggle that was required to find a perspective that yielded the elegant solution. (This may be an American perspective. I remember a scene in Stanislaw Ulam’s “Adventures of a Mathematician” in which he is describing his initial impressions of American physicists and mathematicians when he first came to the States. He describes finding it charming that Americans liked to advertise how hard they worked, while European physicists and mathematicians liked to pretend that everything came to them easily and hide just how hard they were actually working in the background.) None of this is any attempt to claim that being a physicist is harder than any other career choice. I have known musicians, writers, biochemists, etc, who worked as hard if not harder than I do. Hell, I am sure that migrant farm workers work much harder than I ever have. But for all of this I love physics and math, and I don’t at all regret the years I put into them.
